block.p: Sonal Indravadan Pandya, the daughter of Manjula O. Pandya and Indravadan S. Pandya of Union, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Sunil Suresh Dalal, a son of Bharti S. Dalal and Suresh T. Dalal of Hayward, Calif. Pandit Suresh M. Bhatt, a Hindu priest, is to perform the ceremony at Birchwood Manor in Whippany, N.J.

The bride, 30, is the manager of the climate change program at Conservation International, an environmental preservation group in Washington. She is also a member of the national board of the Network of Indian Professionals, a business association. She graduated from Drew University and received a master's degree in conservation biology and sustainable development from the University of Maryland. Her father is an agent for Century 21 Plaza Realty, in Jersey City.

The bride, 30, is the manager of the climate change program at Conservation International, an environmental preservation group in Washington. She is also a member of the national board of the Network of Indian Professionals, a business association. She graduated from Drew University and received a master's degree in conservation biology and sustainable development from the University of Maryland. Her father is an agent for Century 21 Plaza Realty, in Jersey City.

Dr. Dalal, 30, is a biomedical engineer at BD Biosciences in San Jose, Calif. He graduated from the University of California at San Diego and received a Ph.D. in biomedical engineering from the University of Southern California. His father retired as a civil and structural engineering consultant in Hayward.

Through Ms. Pandya's parents and Dr. Dalal's aunt and uncle, who knew one another because of business, their families discovered last summer that each had a child who was single and of an equally marriageable age. It seemed a promising beginning, until Dr. Dalal's uncle and aunt mentioned that their nephew lives in Hayward. The bride's mother feared that her daughter might then marry and move to California.
But Ms. Pandya's father thought otherwise and secretly gave her Dr. Dalal's e-mail address, asking her not to tell her mother.
''He knew I would definitely respond to someone who was intellectual,'' she said. ''And then, of course, the really big thing was that he knew Sunil's aunt and uncle were a good family.''
Dr. Dalal said that he and Ms. Pandya didn't mind that their relatives were broadcasting their availability.
''We're both professionals, so we don't have that much time for looking on our own,'' he said. ''So any help we could get from family and friends was appreciated.''

Ms. Pandya sent a message to Dr. Dalal, who phoned her that very evening. They met a few weeks later, when Dr. Dalal traveled to Washington on business. Within four months, after seeing each other every month and exchanging e-mail messages and phone calls several times a day, they were talking about when they should marry.
Dr. Dalal said that even in their first conversation, a match seemed possible.
''I like an independent woman, and it was important for me that she had a career that she believes in and doesn't have to rely on her man to tell her what to do,'' he said.
The bride, as her mother feared, is going to relocate to California. But Mrs. Pandya has decided that distance is not as important to her as her daughter's happiness.
''Now I think, 'Good,' '' she said. ''The boy is good, the family is good, everything is good.''
